text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
I've got the easiest curry ever to share with

you it's so easy in fact that it is the one that 
we make the most often at home in Thailand it's

something called gaeng som so gaeng is curry and 
som means sour so yes it is a sour curry that's

more like a soup if you were to look at it sort 
of from a Western standpoint it's very light very

thin super delicious the version that I'm making 
today is skank so Malacca and Malacca is papaya

so it's a dish that contains green papaya which 
a lot of people look at green papaya and they're

only thinking salad but it's actually a really 
really versatile vegetable so let's get started

so as always I'm gonna make the curry paste 
first and this is the symbol is curry raised

ever I'm starting with some dried chilies I don't 
like my gang some to be very spicy so I'm using

today the bigger ones this is ygo peppers and I'm 
adding just a few our bold chilies for that extra

spiciness you can make it as spicy or as mild 
as you wish okay just gonna take the seats out

by cutting these into chunks who to the chilies 
I'm gonna add some shallots and garlic that I've

chopped and a little salt and of course some 
shrimp paste if you are vegetarian you do not

have to add the shrimp paste you can have some 
miso paste instead this curry paste does not have

a lot of ingredients so the shrimp place flavor 
will actually come out quite a bit so if you're

sort of new to it don't add too much otherwise it 
might be a little too shrimp pasty and now this is

hard to find but it's really important in gang 
so this is called crotch high or in English is

called finger root now I know this label says 
rhizome and brine which is as descriptive as

calling an apple fruit I can't get this fresh so 
the fresh ones look like in the label here but the

stuff in brine is actually really really good the 
smell is still strong and really true to what the

fresh fruits smell like if you can't find it oh 
I'm gonna say well you know what what can you do

right so you gotta skip it there's nothing you can 
substitute with it really smells similar you could

try galangal but it's really quite different 
look in your Asian grocery stores Vietnamese

stores will often have it as well sometimes it's 
shredded like mine is here sometimes it's whole so

take a look ask around so since this curry paste 
will not be sauteed I can actually add some water

and blend it makes my life easy I don't need 
to you know fight with it you can of course do

this in a mortar and pestle but this is one of 
the rare occasions where you can just add water

and blend all right yes there are still little 
flakes of chillies don't worry about it that's

okay it'll add a little character to the curry 
so first of all check out my beautiful new pot

it was on a crazy sale so I couldn't stop myself 
but any case in this beautiful pot I've got some

unsalted pork stock you can do chicken stock you 
can do fish stock now gang sum is unique in that

it's brothy but the way you thicken the curry 
is with fish so I've got here some Cod but for

this you can use any mild flavored fish that you 
have even leftovers would be fine make sure it's

inexpensive I mean don't do this with $20 a pound 
halibut because we're gonna like smush it up to

nothing so I'm gonna just cook this fish really 
quick in this pot here in this broth here so the

fish is fully cooked now I'm gonna take this out 
transfer it in my mortar and pestle here just so

I can mooch it up and by the way you can put as 
much fish or as little fish as you like depending

on how thick you want it some people don't put 
the fish at all back to the curry pot I'm gonna

turn the heat back on so now my curry paste is 
just gonna go straight in I mean this is one of

those a water-based curry if you read my book 
you know all about water-based curry but water

based curries generally doesn't involve sauteing 
the paste in advance you just dissolve it right

in so this is why I said it's more like a soup so 
it's light brothy and delicious and let that come

to a simmer I'm going to add my fish also and 
by the way don't use canned tuna I've done that

before it does not taste good that you want mild 
flavor before I add my vegetables I'm going to add

my seasoning so when I put my vegetables in it has 
some seasoning to absorb right so of course fish

sauce as per usual some palm sugar to balance 
the salt and also the acid which will add in a

second this is key ingredient right here tamarind 
I'm using tamarind concentrate or what I refer to

as tamarind juice this is the main sour flavor and 
you cannot have gangs home without Terran tamarin

sourness varies from brand to brand so I always 
just start with three tablespoons than I taste

and adjust from there so while that's coming to 
a simmer I want to talk to you about vegetables

so I mentioned this is gangsta melaka which is 
papaya so that's my green papaya right there

that I cut up in today's wedges now if you're 
wondering what green papaya looks like thank

you very much tada this is a green papaya it's 
not a different variety of a paya it's just an

under ripe papaya but I like to go with the bigger 
ones it's more substantial if you get like one of

those little Hawaiian papayas there the meat is 
so thin so I like to stick with the bigger one so

it's the same one you use for green papaya salad 
right when it comes to gang so my like a lot of

different types of vegetables so there's lots of 
things to choose from so some classic choices are

napa cabbage which I've chopped up some carrots 
which I made into beautiful little stars here and

what I did was that I use a julienne peeler and 
peeled the carrot and then just slice them and

the julienne peeler will create this beautiful 
edge that makes a carrot so much more festive

and super easy to do and if you're interested in 
buying the julienne peeler it is listed in my kit

of with that link in the description below and 
some dark green color and crunchiness I've got

some long beans here that I just cut up okay so 
it's coming to a boil now I'm going in with papaya

and carrots which will take longer to cook and the 
papaya in my experience takes about 10 minutes so

eight minutes in I'm gonna add the rest of the 
vegetables which will only take two ooh look at

these so now I just gotta go and just fork these 
papaya okay it's cooked it's still a little firm

that's okay because it still got a couple more 
minutes the napa cabbage and the long beans and

by the way if you're in southern Thailand you 
notice that they're gangshim's is more yellow

and in fact they call it gang Luang which is the 
yellow curry and all they do is they add turmeric

in it does that look pretty ooh beautiful so now 
protein why so gangsol typically typically uses

shrimp so I've got here some shrimp that's been 
peeled and deveined you can do fish you can do

other protein as well it's not wrong I'm just 
showing what's classically done and these are

gonna just take 30 seconds at the most and that 
is it how easy was that that is a legit hiker it

would by the way if you have my book check out 
the gang some version in my book it has pieces

of omelet floating in the soup which goes super 
well so check that out now I'm gonna do a final

tasting to adjust acidity most importantly mmm 
oh that's good but it does need some acidity I

find that the tamron that they have here it's not 
that sour so I always want to finish it with some

lime brightens everything up now you may not need 
the lime okay this depends on your Tamron and I'm

also gonna add just a touch of fish sauce and this 
is something you have to adjust because depending

on how much vegetables you put in what kind of 
vegetables you put in they release different

amounts of water right so always always taste 
now mmm I'm like salivating I mean this reminds

me so much of my mom it's one of our favorite 
curries and it's actually really healthy too

right it's just full of vegetables and herbs 
and and this is of course normally eaten with

rice like all curries but I was not organized 
enough to get the rice cooked in time so I'm

just gonna taste it for you straight up which 
is also delicious so I'm gonna try the papaya

instantly takes me home I mean there's there 
are very few flavors that really communicate

the rustic simple home cooking of Thai cuisine 
better than this one tart with a little sweet and

that aroma of the broth I really comes through 
its it's flavorful yet simple and clean at the

same time and it's really a nice break if you 
know you always stick with the rich coconut

curry this is light and brothy put some rice 
into here and eat it like a rice soup and so

I hope you give this a try the recipe as always 
will be on kaptai kitchen comm when you make it

send me a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram 
and if you haven't subscribed to the show make

sure that you do so you don't miss a recipe and 
also click the little bell icon to make sure you

get a notification when I post a new video if you 
love the show you want to support us check out our

patreon link in the description below and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious tiny
